Part of her throughline, rather

Speaking of Be-ers, the whole reason I watched Karate Kid was because Jim said Mr. Miyagi was a great example of a Be-er. I see how incredible Female he is, but have no idea how he is a Be-er. 
Jim?

Technically I would say that Daniel is a Do-er. I don't use Be-er or Do-er to describe Impact Characters because I think that only confuses things. Sure they often are doers if they impact externally or beers if they impact internally, but I think Approach should be reserved for Main Characters. Likewise with Mental Sex, it is not always the opposite of the Main Character.

True, Jim, you really shouldn't use Do-er or Be-er to describe an Impact Character's behavior (often that holds accurate, but not universally), but I do think it's fair to say that an Impact Character "represents" either the "Do-er argument" or the "Be-er argument", in contrast to the Main Character's argument.
After all, they're in the part of the chart they reside in for a reason.

To me, the problem here is, is that as the story is seen from the MC's POV, could we therefore be sure about the IC approach? Or more importantly, does knowing that make any difference to story? The only thing I would say re. Karate Kid, is that imo, Mr Miyagi changed Daniel's approach from doing something without thought, solving problems externally, to looking inside himself and realising he could be better himself. I guess he still is a do-er though.
@SandyStone I don't know what "represents" means here. Can you spell it out?
What @mikeaja said.

The point of having an Impact Character is that he (or she or it) expresses or embodies an alternative point of view, or argument, or paradigm, to the MC.  But the IC doesn't necessarily express that point of view proactively or even consciously.  For instance, the little boy in "Sling Blade" doesn't know he's having a profound impact on the Billy Bob Thornton character, and certainly isn't trying to, but he definitely "represents" an alternative to the MC's existing and familiar paradigm.  Another for-instance, in Toy Story 1, Buzz Lightyear certainly looks like a Do-er on his own terms, but in terms of his impact on Woody, he "represents" the Be-er argument.
Thanks. I'll have to check out TS1 again, but I'm happy to have something tangible to sink my teeth into.
